net.nologin.meep.tbv

Class Tile

  • java.lang.Object
    • net.nologin.meep.tbv.Tile

  • public class Tile
extends java.lang.Object
    The surface of a TiledBitmapView is rendered using a collection of these Tile objects, each holding a bitmap suitable for rendering a square area of the surface. The view calculates which tiles are required, and fetches them from the TileProvider. Each tile is then rendered at the correct location on the surface.

    Tiles are IDed by their coordinates in a 2D plane. The co-ordinate convention is similar to that of the android canvas. Negative, zero and positive values are permitted, the x values increase rightward, and the y values increase downward. Eg, tile (0,1) is located directly below (0,0), and to the left of (1,1).

    All tiles contain a mutable bitmap, allowing TileProvider implementations to generate the renderable content when ready, and also to clear that content should the tile go off-screen (to save heap memory) without the allocation overhead of creating both Tile and Bitmap objects.

    • Field Detail

      • DEFAULT_TILE_SIZE

        public static final int DEFAULT_TILE_SIZE
        Default tile size, 256 pixels. The actual content of the tile can be scaled by the provider. This size is all about how the SurfaceView is rendered. Too large, and if the Provider is slow, the user will feel like the screen is taking forever to display. Too small, and the number of various method calls to the provider will be excessive. 256px seems to be a good balance.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • size

        public final int size
        Size of the side of the square (pixels)

      • xId

        public final int xId
        X-Coordinate of the tile in the tile grid

      • yId

        public final int yId
        Y-Coordinate of the tile in the tile grid

      • cacheKey

        public final long cacheKey
        Coordinate-based key that is useful for caching. This is an alternative to having an ambiguous hashCode, (two tiles may have the same x,y coordinates, but not the same bitmap data)

    • Method Detail

      • createCacheKey

        public static long createCacheKey(int x,
                  int y)
        Generate a unique ID based on the x and y coordinates could be achieved with a Pair object, but can also be achieved by packing them into the high and low words of a long. See: http://stackoverflow.com/q/919612/276183
        Parameters:
        x - The x coordinate
        y - The y coordinate
        Returns:
        The cache key

      • clearBmpData

        public void clearBmpData()
        Convenience method to set to contained bitmap to null

      • getBitmapContentHash

        public int getBitmapContentHash()
        This method is used by the rendering thread to detect a change in bitmap data. Bitmap hashcodes might be sufficient here, while a bit-by-bit comparison might be expensive. Regardless of implementation, if two tiles return the same value, they'll be assumed to contain the same bitmap data.
        Returns:
        An identifying hashcode for the contained bitmap data. Return 0 to indicate that there is no bitmap data contained in this tile.
